text:
Oh yeah, St Albans is a lovely town!
It's really interesting,  i''m guessing there isn't a set way how to approach what you specialise in then? I've heard in ILM, that cfx artists will do rigging too, but then in other companies, they are two different jobs? And then sometimes, in advertising, groom artists do lookdev too... does it depend on a company then for what pipeline aspects you're responsible for?

About your reel, i did not get it nor the password... I just got a brief description, it would be great to see it though! these are amazing companies you worked at! Did you find it difficult to get into the industry at the beginning or moving from one company to another ( it feels a little bit daunting after hearing about mpc vancouver and I recently watched a documentary about rhythm&hues too, it seems like vfx industry is a tough place to be, yet overwhelmingly exciting).
Also I'm curious what are the examples of Fx/CFX work you would do in a company? Is all the work done in Houdini? and what is it like being a supervisor? I apologise for all these questions, it just all sounds so exciting :sweat_smile:
haha no please throw any questions my way and i'll do my best to answer!

CFX borrows so much from different departments - if you're talking muscle skin etc.. then it can be very tied to rig and animation indeed so some companies might tie the two together more closely which may be what ILM leans toward. In MPC it was all defined under "Tech Anim" so fully seperated from any rigging / anim responsibilities, and the way we approach it at Outpost is similar to that. But as its so simulation based theres a natural route for Fx and Houdini artists to be good at it. I think for muscle / skin the anatomy and movement knowledge of a rigger with the problem solving and workflows of an Fx artist is an ideal combo

Fur is a bit easier... you dont need to worry about the rig side as much so its even more similar to Fx as its essentially just simulating lots of wires. But having a Groomers eye for detail is so important to understand the look and how the groom should hold together and move

groom artists is like i say a whole different thing again, you're right about it being very heavy on lookdev! i think CFX might be the department that most varies between studios in terms of what responsibilities you would have

Getting into the industry was so tough it was a good year and a half after i finished my masters and i somewhat failed that, but i kind of re-grouped and re-focused and finally got an opportunity :slightly_smiling_face: i've found now being in and getting to a certain level its become very easy to move around but i've been quite lucky and i'm sure not everyone would say that

text: so that reels everything up to before Lion King which i cant wait to add! whats crazy is all that came under being in "FX"... despite including making enviroments, facial wound models, pits of animated eels, crowd etc..
so you can acctually have realllyyy varied work as a Houdini artist, makes it very exciting

oh also on the CFX / Tech Anim subject to make matters more confusing is where things like Environment Fx, Cloth Fx come into it. At least from my experience at Dneg in the past these would more likely come under the Fx department but MPC its all "Tech Anim" and comes under that department

that might be type of work related though... i guess dneg would usually be more likely burning capes and crashing through trees than the more character oriented clothing and brushing through grass MPC would do haha
